awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fostering Innovation and Creativity: A National Design Competition in Rehabilitation and Assistive Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to provide a unique opportunity for undergraduate engineering design teams in the area of rehabilitation and assistive devices to showcase their product innovations in a national design competition. This objective will be accomplished through a three-year commitment to support a national design competition hosted at the Summer Biomechanics, Biotransport and Bioengineering Conference (SB3C) where undergraduate design teams from across the country can submit their designs in the area of rehabilitation and assistive devices. The abstracts are reviewed by faculty in the area and the top six teams are invited to attend SB3C and present their work in a special podium session. Each of the finalists will receive $3000 for travel and prototype development. This competition has the potential to also be used as a motivational component to foster innovation and creativity by other faculty teaching design or product development courses. The stability of the competition for the next three years allows the organizer to recruit earlier, and be able to confirm with teams that funds are available for travel and prototyping in advance of the submission deadlines. The SB3C competition will provide an opportunity for faculty across the country to use it as a motivational component in the process of fostering creativity. Undergraduate students attending the conference through their involvement in the competition will learn about bio-solid mechanics, bio-fluid mechanics, device design, rehabilitation, cellular and molecular mechanics, functional tissue engineering, bio-heat and mass transfer, and bioengineering education. Numerous podium sessions, poster sessions, workshops and plenary talks are designed to engage and excite the attendees including the session for the undergraduate design competition. 

The undergraduate design competition will broaden the benefits of the component of motivation to other undergraduate students and their faculty mentors across the country. Further, the materials developed as part of this project will be shared with all faculty mentors involved in prior and future competitions. This competition provides a national venue (with many international attendees) for teams to showcase their innovations in the areas of rehabilitation and assistive devices and compete with their peers. Undergraduate students attending the conference will participate in a research-driven event with technical sessions, workshops and presentations by faculty, clinicians and industrial representatives who have expertise in device design, rehabilitation, disabilities, and numerous other areas. Also, funding will make travel possible for students who otherwise might not attend an academic conference. Attendance at the conference provides valuable networking opportunities for the students, including contacts for graduate school and employment. The inclusion of the competition at the conference also exposes attendees to innovative solutions for needs of individuals with disabilities, or those undergoing rehabilitation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of Fostering Innovation and Creativity: A National Design Competition in Rehabilitation and Assistive Devices, was to provide teams of undergraduate engineering students involved in creating, designing, and developing innovative technologies in the area of Rehabilitative and Assistive Devices an opportunity to showcase their work at the Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and BioTransport Conference (SB3C) which is held annually and attended by prominent academic scientists and engineers, industry partners, and federal agencies. The SB3C conference also hosts the annual meetings of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Bioengineering Division (ASME-BED) and the related Committees, including the Design, Dynamics, and Rehabilitation (DDR) Committee which organized these design competitions.

The project extended over three years (2019-2021). For all competitions, teams of undergraduate students from across North America submitted abstracts about their design projects through the SB3C conference abstract submission portal. Judges drawn from the ASME-BED DDR committee then identified the top six abstracts (deemed ?finalists?) using a scoring rubric provided by the competition organizers. The finalists were then invited to present a podium presentation at the SB3C conference. Certificates were awarded to all members of the teams identified as finalists. Plaques were then awarded to the top three teams based on the podium presentations, as determined by judges recruited from those attending the conference, which included academic researchers, industry partners, and federal agency members. To broaden the impact of the competition, teams that were not chosen as finalists were also invited to present via a poster session at the SB3C event. 

All teams selected as finalists for the 2019 event were granted $3K awards to help cover costs associated with participation in the live in-person podium session. In 2020 and 2021, due to COVID concerns, the competition was held as a virtual event and compensation for travel was not necessary, though all participants had their conference fees covered.  

In 2019, the top three teams were:

3rd Place: Texas A&M University - "Design of 3D Printed Robotic Glove Augmenting Manual Manipulation of Humans", Mason Araujo and Immanuel Ponminissery, (Faculty Advisor: Dr. Seok-Chang Ryu) 

2nd Place: University of Texas at Arlington Research Institute, "Wearable Robotic Wrist Orthosis for Stoke Rehabilitation", Neshat Baset and Dona Antony Seth Patterson, (Faculty Advisors: Mahdi Haghshenas-jaryani and Muthu B.J. Wijesundara)

1st Place: Widener University "Assistive Device for Stretching Exercise in Patients with Frozen Shoulder Syndrome", Maria C Owsiak, Mansour A Al Awami, Ryan J Daher, Scott J Goeltz, Rebecca I Gomezrueda, Russell E Maurer, Andrew N Saylor, (Faculty Advisor: Dr. Ria Mazumder) 

In 2020, the top three teams were:

3rd Place: Clarkson University - ?Stoma Submersion Security: A Precautionary Device for Accidental Water Submersion?, Megan E. DeRidder, Daphne A. Freeman, Megan A. McCann, Jenna A. Russ, Molly E. Stewart, (Faculty Advisor: Byron D. Erath, PhD)

2nd Place: University of Mount Union - ?Design Of A Facility-Owned Adjustable Interim Prosthetic?, Matthew Honaker, Masashi Nisiguchi, Hanna Wharton, Logan Palochak, (Faculty Advisors: Joshua Gargac, PhD)

1st Place: University of Texas at Arlington - ?A Lightweight Wearable American Sign Language Alphabet Translation Device?, Prissha Krishna Moorthy, Jennifer Tran, Thao Thu Nguyen, Karmina Calderon, (Faculty Advisors: Oguz Yetkin, PhD and Khosrow Behbehani, PhD)

In the 2021, the top three were:

3rd Place: The University of Alabama - ?Haptic Feedback to Aid the Visually Impaired?, Jack Tereck, Carter Roper, Peyton Duersel, Brandon Jackson, Matthew Kamin, (Faculty Advisor: Dario Martelli, PhD)

2nd Place: Washington University in St. Louis - ?The MultiFlex Catheter - A Variable Stiffness Endovascular Catheter?, Halle Lowe,Vinay Chandrasekaran, Chase Hartquist, Mohamed Zayed, (Faculty Advisors: Jin V. Lee, PhD,  Mohammed Zayed, MD PhD, Joshua W. Osbun, MD, Eric C. Leuthhardt, MD, Michael Talcott, DVM, Guy M. Genin, PhD)

1st Place: Northeastern University - ?Ventilators for the Developing World?, Laurie Trainer, Grace Bugara, Taylor Corpuz, Maeve Enright, John Fortescue, Vanessa Zighelboim, (Faculty Advisors: Michael Jaeggli, PhD, Lee Makowski, PhD, and Marc Fuller, PhD)

Overall, approximately 56 diverse undergraduate engineering design teams participated in the design competitions.  Teams had 4 members on average and it is estimated that over 220 students participated in the events. Over 70 faculty mentors worked with the teams. The competitions focused on real world problems and provided real world experience for the teams. Conducting market analysis and a budget plan is required of the participants and part of the evaluation process. Some teams actually formed companies to continue development and commercial their ideas, while others engaged existing companies or industry partners. Some teams also engaged clinical partners during their design process. Participating in the SB3C conference was a significant opportunity for all participants and provided significant guidance and feedback, as well as, unique and substantial networking opportunities with distinguished scientists and industry leaders. The benefit this project offers to society, is the potential availability of new innovative rehabilitative and/or assistive technologies.


Last Modified: 06/23/2022
Modified by: Michael Moreno
